citations.title: [Deep RL for Prescribed Fire Planning]( (Environmental Modelling & Software, 2021)
[Multi-Agent RL for Coverage]( (arXiv, 2019) — General coverage, not wildfire
[Path Planning for Firefighting Robots]( (IEEE, 2020) — Ground robots, not drones
1. **[Reinforcement Learning for Wildfire Resource Allocation]( (Ganapathi Subramanian & Crowley, arXiv 2021) — RL for wildfire, but resource allocation not drone control
2. **[Deep Reinforcement Learning for Prescribed Fire Planning]( (Houtman et al., Environmental Modelling & Software 2021) — RL for fire planning
3. **[Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Drone Swarms]( (Hu et al., arXiv 2020) — MARL for drones, not wildfire
4. **[Learning to Fly by Crashing]( (Gandhi et al., arXiv 2017) — RL for drone control
5. **[Sim-to-Real Transfer in Robotics]( (Tobin et al., arXiv 2017) — Domain randomization
6. **[Safe Reinforcement Learning]( (García & Fernández, arXiv 2018) — Safe RL survey

judges.raw: {"score":1,"rationale":"The response notes technical risks such as payload capacity limitations, flight time constraints, safety issues (e.g., flying near fire/smoke, creating fire to fight fire), scalability, communication failures, simulation fidelity, validation challenges, computational requirements, and regulatory hurdles. It provides mitigation ideas including starting with simple simulations and existing tools (e.g., cellular automata + AirSim/Gazebo), using mature RL algorithms like PPO/SAC, scaling from single-agent to multi-agent, focusing on simulation and historical data for validation, partnering with fire agencies, and incorporating safe RL with human-in-the-loop approaches.","confidence":"high"}
judges.rationale: The response notes technical risks such as payload capacity limitations, flight time constraints, safety issues (e.g., flying near fire/smoke, creating fire to fight fire), scalability, communication failures, simulation fidelity, validation challenges, computational requirements, and regulatory hurdles. It provides mitigation ideas including starting with simple simulations and existing tools (e.g., cellular automata + AirSim/Gazebo), using mature RL algorithms like PPO/SAC, scaling from single-agent to multi-agent, focusing on simulation and historical data for validation, partnering with fire agencies, and incorporating safe RL with human-in-the-loop approaches.
